Despite efforts from some service providers and other nations to take the site down or restrict access, Sanctioned Suicide continues to reemerge with new domain names and remains easily accessible via a simple Google search. We share a bipartisan commitment to changing that.

Owners of the website try to limit legal liability by encouraging anonymity, requiring users to be over 18 years old, and deleting accounts of users after they have posted ‚Äògoodbye‚Äô threads. But @nytimes identified at least three victims under 18. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2021/12/09/us/where-the-despairing-log-on.html

In addition to discussing ways to die by suicide, anonymous users routinely encourage each other to attempt to take their own lives, offering praise for those who follow through. Sanctioned Suicide has 6 million views per month and nearly half of all users are under 25 years old.

A @nytimes investigative report found that only 5 percent of posts on Sanctioned Suicide are focused on recovery. More than half of the top 100 posts on the site include instructions or discussions of methods to die by suicide. 28 of those posts narrate suicide attempts.

Warning: Before reading further, this thread describes the threats posed by Sanctioned Suicide in detail and can be distressing. If you or someone you know are having thoughts of suicide, please contact the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 800-273-8255 (TALK).

Sen. @JerryMoran and I have repeatedly said the process and policy for determining liver allocations needs to be made fairly and transparently. Neither UNOS nor the Department of Health and Human Services have lived up to this standard.
The emails further include profane and disparaging comments about people living in the South, demonstrating a clear bias against these areas in the policymaking process.
The changes favored certain states at the expense of states in the South and Midwest, which are predicted to see a substantial decrease in organ availability.

After reviewing emails that were just released between UNOS and organ procurement organizations and transplant hospitals, we now know that there was a pattern of collusion prior to the changes in the liver allocation policy being announced.

We knew that UNOS overruled the expert Liver and Intestine Committee, excluded certain public comments in the deliberations, and arrived at an outcome that was radically different from the decision previously reached.

Thanks to a recent appeals court ruling against UNOS, we have now learned that the process was more than just fundamentally flawed ‚Äì it was deliberately designed to deny people in the South and Midwest a fair chance at a lifesaving liver transplant.

Three years ago, the United Network for Organ Sharing made major, misguided changes to the national liver allocation policy. Since that time, Sen. @JerryMoran and I have repeatedly raised the alarm about the new policy and the deeply flawed process by which it came about.
